attributes.title: Analyzing public health policy implementation processes – a systematic map

q1.value: Analyzing public health policy implementation processes – a systematic map

q2.value: Sarah Forberger, Aleksandra Luszczynska, Łobczowska Karolina, Lien Nanna, Meshkovska Biljana, Scheller Daniel, Wendt Janine, Lucia Reisch, Hajo Zeeb, Christianson Lara

q3.value:
Building on work done within Policy Evaluation Network PEN and flanking the work in PEN WP 4 (frameworks and determinants and barriers for implementation), the systematic map will identify variables and variable constellations associated with implementation processes. We will analyze the role and significance of these variables in different policy fields under different. Reflecting the health focus of the Policy Evaluation Network (Lakerveld et al., 2019 PEN Statement paper), we will focus on the policies: sweetened beverages (SSB) taxation, promotion of physical activity and of active transport. These three policy fields differ systematically with regard to the preferred policy types (regulatory, distributive, constituent, redistributive), main instruments applied (communicative, regulatory,
economic means), and implementation style (centralized vs. decentralized). More concrete: While SSB taxation as financial instrument is a core competence of the state, the field of physical activity promotion is characterized by a mix of policy instruments that will depend on target group, setting, culture, and wider political context. Active transport, on the other hand, might be largely predetermined by the implemented technical-administrative system.
By combining approaches from implementation science and public policy, we will investigate the relationship between types of policy and instrument used, implementation actors and styles, context factors, the interplay of different variables and their explanatory value for the implementation process in a comparative way (i.e., cross-country variation, within country variation in different sectors). 

Research question

Aim of the work is first, to identify variables that are associated with implementation processes, and second, to investigate how these variables interact to describe and explain implementation processes. The overall research question of the study is: Are there core variables and process patterns of public policy implementation processes that can be identified for specific policies (SSB taxation, PA promotion, active transport) and between countries targeting the whole population?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
A search string will be developed by the author team with the help of our research librarian. The search will
be developed in an iterative process. The search string will be tested and refined by examining the research
results. Each database will be searched for keywords and applicable subject terms. The final search string will
be applied in all databases with appropriate syntax adaptions. Databases covered are Medline, Embase, PsycInfo, WoS, CINHAL, Econ.Lit, ASSIA, DAIS, PAIS, ERIC. 

Grey Literature
In addition to the bibliographic databases, a modified search string will be used to identify other grey
literature. The resources to be searched will include selected repositories as well as Google Scholar
(Haddaway, Collins, Coughlin, & Kirk, 2015; Reisch et al., 2019). This search will help to identify working
papers, policy documents, dissertations, and other unpublished or non-indexed literature. The results
will be added to the workflow for duplicate removal and further processing.
Supplementary Search
The identified and included papers will screened for additional references.
In addition, we will carry out the following search activities to identify studies that may have been
missed in the database search:
- Reaching out to experts in the field as well as sending out a social media request to provide
us with respective studies (not published)
see Table 7 in the attached file

Results will be mapped in accordance to the extraction sheet. A narrative syntheses of the evidence
found will be given. Various forms of visualization, such as tables and charts will be used to present the
data. Group and boundaries of the data presentation will depend on the evidence retrieved.

attributes.title: Psychometric analysis of the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire in Czech Republic
attributes.description: This study aims to complexly evaluate psychometric quality of the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire in terms of internal consistency, factor structure and construct validity.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Psychometric analysis of the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire in Czech Republic.

sample.value: We determine the sample size based on desired value of fit index i.e. RMSEA, which is highly sensitive to sample size. As we have decided to divide our data on the two parts and on the one part perform EFA, whereas on the another perform CFA, we should have approximately equal number of participants in both parts. Thus, sample size estimate for CFA also indicated number of participants for EFA.

analyses.value:
Selection of the statistical methods will depend on the features of the collected
data. However, if assumptions will be met, then the factor structure of the questionnaire will be examined by a) exploratory factor analysis (EFA) and b) confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) using polychoric correlation matrix in both cases. The reliability of the scale will be tested via
Cronbach’s alpha and McDonald’s omega. Group differences will be tested via parametrical
methods if the assumptions will be met, if not, then non-parametrical methods will be used.
Convergent validity of the questionnaires will be examined mainly via correlations.

outliers.value:
In contrast to this traditional method, we will use median absolute deviation (MAD) for outlier detection. As recommended by Leys, et al., (2013), we treated values as outlying if they lied above 2.5 times of MAD or below - 2.5 times of MAD.  Cases in which outliers will be 
found will be complexly screened. Aim of this screening will be to detect uniform pattern of responding, multiple logical incongruences or other information suggesting that these cases should be excluded from the analysis.

dependent.value: The dependant variable will be trait empathy score as measured by the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire.

conditions.value: Each participant in our study will be assigned to basic socio-demographic groups. Based on reported education, economical status, religiosity and gender. In case of the lastly mentioned group, it will be used one factorial design to test, whether males and females differ with respect to empathy score.

hypothesis.value:
H1: Alternative factor models of the Toronto Empathy Questionnaire (TEQ) will explain data better compared to originally suggested one dimensional model.
H2: TEQ items containing double negatives will decrease internal consistency of the scale compared to reformulated, positively worded items.  
H3: There will be positive association between TEQ score and social desirability.
H4: Empathy score will be positively associated with compassion.
H5: There will be positive correlation between empathy and spirituality. 
H6: Females, will display significantly higher level of empathy compared to males.
H7: Trait neuroticism will be weakly or nonsignificantly associated with empathy.
H8: Empathy will not be associated with self-esteem.

study_type_other.value: This form has a character of pre-registration prior to analysis of the data. Our data are collected from several studies, which however did not test factor structure and validity of TEQ. In order to support the validity of such studies results, we have decided to explore factor structure and validity of TEQ on already collected data.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Memory misinformation and jury decision-making. A study to investigate whether memory misinformation can occur during jury deliberations to effect judgments made by (mock) jurors.

other.value:
One-way ANOVAs will be conducted to explore the effect of misinformation condition and pre-deliberation guilt and credibility ratings to ensure that there are no initial differences across the groups (prior to the experimental manipulation) due to the randomisation process. Likewise, a chi-square analysis will be conducted to determine whether pre-deliberation verdict (guilty/not guilty) is related to misinformation condition. 

In the simulated jury deliberations, participants are asked to answer some questions about the trial. The real participant is always the first to respond to these questions so that we can determine their memory for critical items prior to misinformation exposure. We will look at participants' responses to these questions in the simulated deliberation to determine whether there is any spontaneous reporting of misinformation items by participants prior to exposure to the misinformation.

sample.value: Based on a priori power calculations, a sample of N = 267 is required to achieve 90% power, given the design, main planned analyses and assumed effect size (moderate; Lovakov & Agadullina, 2018).  We will also collect up to N = 30 participants prior to the main sample as pilot data to ensure the simulated deliberation software is working without technical issues. Pilot data will be included in the final sample if the deliberation software and questionnaire work without technical issues.

analyses.value:
H1: To determine whether acceptance of misinformation (through free recall and source monitoring test) differs across misinformation conditions - a one-way ANOVA will be conducted for each analysis, with planned contrasts comparing consistent misinformation to contradictory misinformation and the two consistent misinformation conditions. 

H2: To explore the effect of misinformation condition on post-deliberation guilt and credibility ratings - one-way ANOVAs will be conducted to explore whether differences in guilt ratings and credibility from pre- to post-deliberation differ as a function of misinformation condition. Planned contrasts will be conducted to compare each of the three groups. A chi-square test of independence will also be conducted to determine whether there is a significant relation between misinformation condition and dichotomous verdict. 

H3: To determine whether the relationship between misinformation condition and post-deliberation credibility/guilt ratings is mediated by misinformation acceptance, a  parallel multiple mediation analysis will be conducted. Deliberation condition will be the independent variable, and the mediators will be 1) acceptance of pro-defendant misinformation and 2) acceptance of pro-complainant misinformation. The dependent variables will be post-deliberation/guilt ratings.

Secondary Analyses: We will also explore whether perceived credibility of jurors mediates the acceptance of misinformation.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded if they indicate they found anything about the study materials suspicious or guess the experimental hypotheses (i.e., became liable to demand characteristics).

dependent.value:
There are three key outcome variables in this study. Participants will complete the defendant guilt and victim credibility items before and after the simulated jury deliberation (which contains the memory misinformation manipulation). Participants will complete the case memory recall test only once after exposure to the memory misinformation manipulation. 

Defendant guilt (2 items; one dichotomous item and one continuous item examining the extent of guilt). These items are used widely in the jury decision-making literature (e.g., see Bornstein et al., 2017). Data from these items will be analysed at the item level. These will be collected both pre- and post- deliberation. 

Victim credibility (4 items; measuring perceptions of victim honesty, believability, credibility and accuracy: adapted from Connolly et al. 2008). We will check to see if ratings across the four items have adequate internal validity (Cronbach's alpha of above .7). If so, a composite score will be created by averaging participants scores over these four items. These will also be collected pre- and post-deliberation

Free recall (1 item). Following deliberation only, participants will be asked to list the details they believe to be important about the case. For free recall, we are interested solely in whether participants report items where misinformation was provided. We will code participant responses for accuracy on misinformation items (e.g. accepted misinformation, rejected misinformation).

Source memory: A source monitoring test will be completed by participants following the free recall test, at the end of the study. The source memory test is adapted from the source memory test used in Ruva et al. (2007). For each item, participants will be asked to state whether the item was presented in the trial only, deliberation only, trial and deliberation, or neither. The primary dependent variable of interest is critical source memory errors (i.e., misinformation acceptance; selecting 'trial' or 'trial and deliberation' for misinformation items).

Participants will also be asked to respond to a suspicion probe (2 items, one dichotomous and one open-ended). These items are included as a data quality check. 

Secondary Measures: We will also include two items assessing the perceived accuracy of the other jurors, as source credibility affects the acceptance of misinformation (Lampinen & Smith, 1995). 

Participant demographics including age, sex, ethnicity and prior jury service will also be collected.

conditions.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned between-subjects to one of three different misinformation conditions:

1. consistent pro-victim: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the alleged victim

2. consistent pro-defendant: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the defendant

3. contradictory: all jurors present different items of misinformation (a mix of pro-defendant and pro-victim)

hypothesis.value:
The current project aims to explore the effect of misinformation during jury deliberation on juror memory and decision-making. Specifically given that jurors deliberate in large groups, we also explored the effect of type of misinformation presented by other mock jurors. There are three different misinformation conditions: 

1. consistent pro-victim: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the alleged victim 

2. consistent pro-defendant: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the defendant

3. contradictory: all jurors present different items of misinformation (a mix of pro-defendant and pro-victim)

We have three key hypotheses:

H1. We expect that misinformation acceptance will be greatest in the consistent conditions compared to the contradictory conditions (based on the findings from Blank [2019]), but we do not anticipate differences in misinformation conditions between the two consistent conditions (i.e. consistent pro-victim vs. consistent pro-defendant)

H2. We expect that post-deliberation guilt ratings and victim credibility ratings will be significantly higher in the consistent pro-victim condition than in the other two conditions. However, it is unclear whether there will be a difference between the consistent pro-defendant condition and the contradictory condition, given that exposure to contradictory misinformation may decrease the perceived strength of the evidence which may reduce guilt and credibility ratings similarly to receiving misinformation that favours the defendant. 

H3. We expect that the relationship between misinformation condition and post-deliberation ratings of guilt and credibility will be mediated by misinformation acceptance, as per the findings of Ruva et al. (2007).

hypothesis.value:
The current project aims to explore the effect of misinformation during jury deliberation on juror memory and decision-making. Specifically given that jurors deliberate in large groups, we also explored the effect of type of misinformation presented by other mock jurors. There are three different misinformation conditions: 

1. consistent pro-victim: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the alleged victim 

2. consistent pro-defendant: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the defendant

3. contradictory: all jurors present different items of misinformation (a mix of pro-defendant and pro-victim)

H1. We expect that misinformation acceptance will be greatest in the consistent conditions compared to the contradictory conditions (based on the findings from Blank [2019]), but we do not anticipate differences in misinformation conditions between the two consistent conditions (i.e. consistent pro-victim vs. consistent pro-defendant)

H2. We expect that post-deliberation guilt ratings and victim credibility ratings will be significantly higher in the consistent pro-victim condition than in the other two conditions. However, it is unclear whether there will be a difference between the consistent pro-defendant condition and the contradictory condition, given that exposure to contradictory misinformation may decrease the perceived strength of the evidence which may reduce guilt and credibility ratings similarly to receiving misinformation that favours the defendant. 

H3. We expect that the relationship between misinformation condition and post-deliberation ratings of guilt and credibility will be mediated by misinformation acceptance, as per the findings of Ruva et al. (2007).

The real participant is always the first to respond to these questions so that we can determine their memory for critical items prior to misinformation exposure. We will look at participants' responses to these questions in the simulated deliberation to determine whether there is any spontaneous reporting of misinformation items by participants prior to exposure to the misinformation.

registration_responses.analyses:
H1: To determine whether acceptance of misinformation (through free recall and source monitoring test) differs across misinformation conditions - a one-way ANOVA will be conducted for each analysis, with planned contrasts comparing consistent misinformation to contradictory misinformation and the two consistent misinformation conditions. 

H2: To explore the effect of misinformation condition on post-deliberation guilt and credibility ratings - one-way ANOVAs will be conducted to explore whether differences in guilt ratings and credibility from pre- to post-deliberation differ as a function of misinformation condition. Planned contrasts will be conducted to compare each of the three groups. A chi-square test of independence will also be conducted to determine whether there is a significant relation between misinformation condition and dichotomous verdict. 

H3: To determine whether the relationship between misinformation condition and post-deliberation credibility/guilt ratings is mediated by misinformation acceptance, a  parallel multiple mediation analysis will be conducted. Deliberation condition will be the independent variable, and the mediators will be 1) acceptance of pro-defendant misinformation and 2) acceptance of pro-complainant misinformation. The dependent variables will be post-deliberation/guilt ratings.

registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded if they indicate they found anything about the study materials suspicious or guess the experimental hypotheses (i.e., became liable to demand characteristics).
registration_responses.dependent:
There are three key outcome variables in this study. Participants will complete the defendant guilt and victim credibility items before and after the simulated jury deliberation (which contains the memory misinformation manipulation). Participants will complete the case memory recall test only once after exposure to the memory misinformation manipulation. 

Defendant guilt (2 items; one dichotomous item and one continuous item examining the extent of guilt). These items are used widely in the jury decision-making literature (e.g., see Bornstein et al., 2017). Data from these items will be analysed at the item level. These will be collected both pre- and post- deliberation. 

Victim credibility (4 items; measuring perceptions of victim honesty, believability, credibility and accuracy: adapted from Connolly et al. 2008). We will check to see if ratings across the four items have adequate internal validity (Cronbach's alpha of above .7). If so, a composite score will be created by averaging participants scores over these four items. These will also be collected pre- and post-deliberation

Free recall (1 item). Following deliberation only, participants will be asked to list the details they believe to be important about the case. For free recall, we are interested solely in whether participants report items where misinformation was provided. We will code participant responses for accuracy on misinformation items (e.g. accepted misinformation, rejected misinformation).

Source memory: A source monitoring test will be completed by participants following the free recall test, at the end of the study. The source memory test is adapted from the source memory test used in Ruva et al. (2007). For each item, participants will be asked to state whether the item was presented in the trial only, deliberation only, trial and deliberation, or neither. The primary dependent variable of interest is critical source memory errors (i.e., misinformation acceptance; selecting 'trial' or 'trial and deliberation' for misinformation items).

Participants will also be asked to respond to a suspicion probe (2 items, one dichotomous and one open-ended). These items are included as a data quality check. 

Secondary Measures: We will also include two items assessing the perceived accuracy of the other jurors, as source credibility affects the acceptance of misinformation (Lampinen & Smith, 1995). 

Participant demographics including age, sex, ethnicity and prior jury service will also be collected.

These will be collected both pre- and post- deliberation. 

Victim credibility (4 items; measuring perceptions of victim honesty, believability, credibility and accuracy: adapted from Connolly et al. 2008). We will check to see if ratings across the four items have adequate internal validity (Cronbach's alpha of above .7). If so, a composite score will be created by averaging participants scores over these four items. These will also be collected pre- and post-deliberation

Free recall (1 item). Following deliberation only, participants will be asked to list the details they believe to be important about the case. For free recall, we are interested solely in whether participants report items where misinformation was provided. We will code participant responses for accuracy on misinformation items (e.g. accepted misinformation, rejected misinformation).

Source memory: A source monitoring test will be completed by participants following the free recall test, at the end of the study. The source memory test is adapted from the source memory test used in Ruva et al. (2007). For each item, participants will be asked to state whether the item was presented in the trial only, deliberation only, trial and deliberation, or neither. The primary dependent variable of interest is critical source memory errors (i.e., misinformation acceptance; selecting 'trial' or 'trial and deliberation' for misinformation items).

Participants will also be asked to respond to a suspicion probe (2 items, one dichotomous and one open-ended). These items are included as a data quality check. 

Secondary Measures: We will also include two items assessing the perceived accuracy of the other jurors, as source credibility affects the acceptance of misinformation (Lampinen & Smith, 1995). 

Participant demographics including age, sex, ethnicity and prior jury service will also be collected.
registration_responses.conditions:
Participants will be randomly assigned between-subjects to one of three different misinformation conditions:

1. consistent pro-victim: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the alleged victim

2. consistent pro-defendant: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the defendant

3. contradictory: all jurors present different items of misinformation (a mix of pro-defendant and pro-victim)
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The current project aims to explore the effect of misinformation during jury deliberation on juror memory and decision-making. Specifically given that jurors deliberate in large groups, we also explored the effect of type of misinformation presented by other mock jurors. There are three different misinformation conditions: 

1. consistent pro-victim: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the alleged victim 

2. consistent pro-defendant: all jurors in deliberation providing the same misinformation regarding details that favour the defendant

3. contradictory: all jurors present different items of misinformation (a mix of pro-defendant and pro-victim)

We have three key hypotheses:

H1. We expect that misinformation acceptance will be greatest in the consistent conditions compared to the contradictory conditions (based on the findings from Blank [2019]), but we do not anticipate differences in misinformation conditions between the two consistent conditions (i.e. consistent pro-victim vs. consistent pro-defendant)

H2. We expect that post-deliberation guilt ratings and victim credibility ratings will be significantly higher in the consistent pro-victim condition than in the other two conditions. However, it is unclear whether there will be a difference between the consistent pro-defendant condition and the contradictory condition, given that exposure to contradictory misinformation may decrease the perceived strength of the evidence which may reduce guilt and credibility ratings similarly to receiving misinformation that favours the defendant. 

H3. We expect that the relationship between misinformation condition and post-deliberation ratings of guilt and credibility will be mediated by misinformation acceptance, as per the findings of Ruva et al. (2007).

q1.value: How does social presence alter emotion expressive behaviour? Expression Collection

q2.value: Tamara Van Der Zant, Nicole  Nelson, Eric Vanman

q3.value:
The presence of other people has been demonstrated to increase and decrease emotional expressions across different contexts. Further, the type of social presence has been found to differentially impact the expressions displayed. The variation in expressive behaviour between different audiences has been most thoroughly examined for the distinction between friends and strangers (Bruder, Dosmukhambetova, Nerb, & Manstead, 2012; Buck, Losow, Murphy, & Costanzo, 1992; Fischer, Becker, & Veenstra, 2012; Hess, Banse, & Kappas, 1995; Jakobs, Manstead, & Fischer, 1999; Jakobs et al., 2001; Schützwohl & Reisenzein, 2012; Wagner & Smith, 1991). Though this research provides evidence that emotion expression can differ across audiences, the distinction between ‘friend’ and ‘stranger’ in such studies is loosely defined and imprecise, and thus provides little explanatory evidence regarding how or why emotion expressions may vary in the presence of different audiences. This research, therefore, seeks to examine how social presence alters expressive behaviour by replicating the typical friend and stranger paradigm to establish that prior reported findings are robust. 

The research will be conducted in two phases. This pre-registration details the Expression phase in which expressions will be collected from participants as they view emotion eliciting stimuli. The Perception phase of the research will entail taking expressions collected in this first phase and presenting them to a separate sample of participants who will evaluate the expressions.

This pre-registration will, therefore, detail the stimuli collection methods but will not contain any hypotheses as the expressions will serve as a stimulus set used to collect data during the subsequent phase of research. Hypotheses and analysis plans will be included in the pre-registration of the Perception phase.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value:
All participants will be blind to the focus of the research, namely, their expressed emotions. Participants will only be made aware that their expressions were observed and recorded at the completion of the task and will then be asked to provide consent for film of them to be used further. This blinding to the study's purpose will hopefully prevent participants from monitoring or altering their expressive behaviour. 

Participants in the strangers and alone conditions will not be aware that the presence or absence of the additional person is relevant to the study and will thus be blind to that manipulation. In the friends condition, participants will be aware that they are participating with a friend but will not be aware that other conditions exist or the relevance of the presence of the friend.

question.value:
This phase of the research will collect stimuli that will be used in the subsequent phase of research. Participants will be assigned to one of three social conditions (Solo, Stranger or Friend) and will view 8 emotion eliciting film segments. 

The videos recorded of these participants will be used in the subsequent stage of research which will be pre-registered and the design for the collection of data will be defined.

q9.value:
Social Condition Randomisation: Participants in the friends condition will not be able to be randomised. For all of the sessions testing the strangers and solo conditions, we will attempt to recruit two participants. When two participants are available to be tested, they will be assigned to the stranger condition and tested together, and when only one participant is available, they will be tested in the solo condition. Once the stranger condition is complete, the remaining participants will be assigned to the solo condition until it is complete.

Stimuli Randomisation: Both the expression and perception phase stimuli will be presented randomly with randomisation controlled by the software Qualtrics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Participants will primarily be recruited from the undergraduate psychology student body in return for course credit toward a from

question.value: Participants will primarily be recruited from the undergraduate psychology student body in return for course credit toward a first year psychology course. The exception is in the friend condition in which one participant will be recruited from the undergraduate psychology student body as described above, but they will be instructed to bring a friend who will be financially reimbursed ($20 AUD) for their participation. There will not be specific requirements for the friends recruited by other participants.

q13.value: We will be collecting at least 90 participants, 30 for each condition, with 8 trials each, resulting in a total of 720 expressions to be used in the Perceiving phase of research.

q14.value: Sample size has been determined both by feasibility and in an attempt to reach appropriate power. This phase of the research, therefore, will have a sample size in excess of that which is common in the literature and will include repeated measures to ensure adequate power.

question.value:
Social Presence : Friend, stranger or none. Participants will either participate alone, with a friend, or with a stranger.

Video stimuli: Clips from films will be used as stimuli. However we will not be expecting specific emotional responses to each stimuli. Instead stimuli have been selected as they have been found to elicit a range of emotion categories, valence and arousal. We will be using participant's self-reported emotion experience to identify expressions and video stimuli will be a random factor to be accounted for rather than examined (mixed effects model to be defined in pre-registration of subsequent phase of research).

Experienced emotion from Expressing phase participants:
- Self-report emotion experienced (How did watching that video make you feel?)
- Self-report intensity of emotion experienced (How much did the video make you feel
[emotion selected above]?)
- Self-reported valence and arousal (Did the video make you feel more positive or negative?
Did the video make you feel more or less energised/agitated?)

Personality: The NEO-FFI (REFERENCE) will be used to provide a measure of the Big-Five Personality factors. Extraversion will be the main factor of interest, though the other 4 of the Big Five Personality factors will be included, both to mask which personality feature is of interest and to provide the option of exploratory analysis of the other factors.

Gender: Male, female and other will be provided as options. Analyses will only compare male and female gender because we have no hypotheses in relation to other genders.

Culture: This will be somewhat dependent on the sample available as participants will not be recruited specifically on the basis of cultural background. We plan, initially, to separate groups born in Western and Eastern countries, and may explore more specific contrasts (e.g. born in Australia vs. China) depending on the composition of our sample. 

Friendship type: Only presented to those in the friend condition of the expressing phase of research to better characterise the sample and to explore how variation in relationship may alter expressive behaviour (How would you categorise your relationship with the person you participated in the study with? - Multiple choices: Best friend, Good Friend, Casual Friend, Classmate, Coworker, Friend of a friend, Acquaintance, Stranger).

Stranger check: Only presented to those in the stranger condition of the expressing phase of research to ensure they were not friends before participating together (How well do you know the person you participated with today? - Multiple choices: Met for the first time today; We have met before but I don't know them well; I know them very well).

Liking, Closeness and Similarity: Five items from Sprecher, Treger, Wondra, Hilaire and Wallpe (2013) will be used to assess the interpersonal relationship between friend and stranger dyads.
As no data is collected in this phase of research (only stimuli) no statistical analysis plans will be described here.

q23.value:
Participants will be screened for whether they were aware they were being filmed or that expressions were the research interest. Should they be aware of either, their expressions will be excluded. 

Additionally, if expressing participants' expressions are not visible to the camera (i.e. head turned away from camera or moved out of shot), those expressions will be excluded.

name.value: The ethical consumer: psychological aspects influencing ethical purchasing behavior based on the TPB

sample.value: As we specified 7 estimated parameter in our model, we want to collect 350 observations (50:1 ratio of observations to estimated parameters)

analyses.value: Structural equitation model (for H1 and H2); F-Tests (for H4 and H5)

outliers.value: Exclusion criteria: (a) Persons who do not purchase at all (b) Persons whose values for social desirability are more than 2 standard deviations above the norm

dependent.value: As main dependent variable we measure the actual ethical buying behavior which is operationalized as the frequency in which the participants in the past 6 months preferred an ethical product over a conventional one or deliberately avoided a “non-ethical” product (measured on a 5-point Likert scale from not at all to exclusively). The participants specify this for each ethical dimension (animal welfare, the environment, human rights/ working conditions/ fair-trade) separately.

conditions.value: Since we collect our data though a survey, the participants aren't assigned to any conditions.

hypothesis.value: H1: The intention to buy ethical products has an influence on the actual ethical buying behavior. H2: Attitudes towards ethical products, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control (PBC), perceived consumer effectiveness as well as the self-identity of consumer have an influence on the intention to buy ethical products; PBC also has an influence on actual ethical buying behavior. H3: The intention-behavior-gap does not differ between different dimensions of ethical consumption (animal welfare, the environment, human rights/ working conditions/ fair-trade). H4: The different dimensions of ethical consumption are equally weighted: The strength of the influences between the factors on the intention to buy products (H2) does not differ between the dimensions.

attributes.title: Relationship Between Social Media and Mental Health: Examining Type and Time Spent on Social Media on Adverse Mental Health Outcomes

q1.value: Relationship Between Social Media and Mental Health: Examining Type and Time Spent on Social Media on Adverse Mental Health Outcomes

q3.value:
There has been conflicting evidence to whether there is a relationship between social media and mental health variables. Newer research has been looking at specific types of social media usage and its relationship to mental health. However, while there have been studies to identify whether those who use Facebook are more likely to have poor mental health outcomes depending on if they use the app passively or actively, there has been no such study done on other types of social media sites, such as Instagram and Snapchat. Additionally, very few studies have begun to examine the relationship between time spent on social media, type of social media, and passive and active use on mental health variables in one concise study. 

The research questions this study seeks to answer are the following:
1. Is there a difference between type of social networking site (SNS) on a participant’s reported anxiety, self-esteem, physical attractiveness, and subjective well-being?
2. Are those who spend more time on SNS more likely to report positive attitudes towards, than those who spend less time on SNS?
3. Are those who use SNS passively more likely to score higher on adverse mental health outcomes?

q4.value:
There are three non-directional hypotheses in this study which include the following:

Ho1: There is no difference between type of SNS (Highly visual vs not highly visual) on mental health variables. 
Ha1: There is a difference between type of SNS (High visual vs not highly visual) on mental health variables.


Ho2: There is no difference in attitudes toward social media for those who spend more time on social media versus those who spend less. 
Ha2: There is a difference in attitudes toward social media for those who spend more time on social media versus those who spend less.

Ho3: There is not a difference in negative mental health levels in those who passively use social media compared to those who actively use social media.
Ha3: There is a difference in negative mental health levels in those who passively use social media compared to those who actively use social media.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will be a quasi-experimental/correlational design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from classrooms at a U.S private university.

q13.value: The target sample size is 150 participants.

question.value:
There are seven variables that will be measured in this study, these include, passive SNS usage, time spent on SNS, subjective well-being, anxiety, physical attractiveness, self-esteem, and attitude towards social media. 

Time spent on SNS will be measured by having the participants report their time spent on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, and Snapchat by going into their settings and clicking battery, then they will click “Show activity by app” and will manually input how much time they spend on each respective app into the free answer question on SurveyMonkey. If the participant does not have one of the apps, they will put their time spent on that app as 0 minutes.

To measure active and passive usage, the participants will answer a 6-item list of questions developed by Hendrickse, Arpan, Clayton, & Ridgway (2017). Because of the nature of the questions on this scale, passive use will be determined by the degree to which a participant scores on active SNS use. Thus, the lower the participant scores on active use, the more passive their social media behavior is. Participants will respond on 5-point scale and will be asked to indicate the likelihood of engaging in SNS behaviors. On this scale, 1 will be ranked as least likely and 5 will be ranked as most likely to engage in a behavior.

Subjective well-being  will be measured by having participants take the 5-item Satisfaction with Life Scale (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985). This scale is a 7-point scale with ranges from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

Anxiety will be measured using an IPIP scaled that has been derived from the Hexaco Anxiety scale (Goldberg et al., 2006).  This is a 10-item scale where participants will respond to a series of statements on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (very inaccurate) to 5 (very accurate). 

Physical Attractiveness will be measured by a 9-item IPIP scale based on The Hypomanic Personality Scale developed by Mark Eckblad and Loren Chapman (1986). Participants will then respond to each item on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (very inaccurate) to 5 (very accurate).  

Self-Esteem levels will be measured by using a 10-item IPIP self-esteem scale that’s adapted from Morris Rosenberg’s Self-Esteem Scale (1965). All items are answered using a 4-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). 

Attitude towards social media will be measured by using a scale developed by Crites, Fabrigar, & Petty (1994). This will measure the affective and cognitive properties of attitudes towards SNS by having a series of word pairs. Participants will then choose a point along a 7-point bipolar continuum to indicate how strongly they feel the word describes Social Media.  The questions that will be included in this survey are attached.

question.value: We will be conducting an independent samples t-test to see if there is a difference between type of social media platforms (Highly visual vs not highly visual) on self-esteem, anxiety, and subjective well-being. To assess the difference in attitudes toward social media for those who spend more time on social media versus those who spend less, the anticipated statistical analyses is Pearson’s R to assess the degree and trend of the relationship between the two variables. The analysis that will be conducted to see if passive/active use and SNS type predicts the mental health outcome variables is a multivariate multiple regression.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: I will verify that each subject answered all of the survey. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete all of the survey, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

Subjective well-being  will be measured by having participants take the 5-item Satisfaction with Life Scale (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985). This scale is a 7-point scale with ranges from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree). 

Anxiety will be measured using an IPIP scaled that has been derived from the Hexaco Anxiety scale (Goldberg et al., 2006).  This is a 10-item scale where participants will respond to a series of statements on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (very inaccurate) to 5 (very accurate). 

Physical Attractiveness will be measured by a 9-item IPIP scale based on The Hypomanic Personality Scale developed by Mark Eckblad and Loren Chapman (1986). Participants will then respond to each item on a 5-point scale ranging from 1 (very inaccurate) to 5 (very accurate).  

Self-Esteem levels will be measured by using a 10-item IPIP self-esteem scale that’s adapted from Morris Rosenberg’s Self-Esteem Scale (1965). All items are answered using a 4-point scale ranging from 1 (strongly disagree) to 4 (strongly agree). 

Attitude towards social media will be measured by using a scale developed by Crites, Fabrigar, & Petty (1994). This will measure the affective and cognitive properties of attitudes towards SNS by having a series of word pairs. Participants will then choose a point along a 7-point bipolar continuum to indicate how strongly they feel the word describes Social Media.  The questions that will be included in this survey are attached.

registration_responses.q19.question: We will be conducting an independent samples t-test to see if there is a difference between type of social media platforms (Highly visual vs not highly visual) on self-esteem, anxiety, and subjective well-being. To assess the difference in attitudes toward social media for those who spend more time on social media versus those who spend less, the anticipated statistical analyses is Pearson’s R to assess the degree and trend of the relationship between the two variables. The analysis that will be conducted to see if passive/active use and SNS type predicts the mental health outcome variables is a multivariate multiple regression.

q2.value: Rotem Kahalon, Orly Bareket, Hila Zitelny

q3.value:
The purpose of the present study is to provide further support for the predictive validity of the Madonna-Whore Dichotomy (MWD) questionnaire by showing that the attitudes it assesses are associated with implicit MWD attitudes, as measured by the IAT. 
As previous research found that the MWD is related to decreased sexual satisfaction and relationship satisfaction (Bareket et al., 2018; Kahalon et al., 2019), we will also examine whether participants performance in the IAT will be related to their relationship and sexual satisfaction. 
We will also use semi-implicit measure again (picture rating task), to examine whether the implicit and explicit measures both relate to the semi-implicit measure. 
We will also examine whether the MWD measures are correlated with feelings and attitudes against breastfeeding in public. Negative attitudes of both men and women toward public breastfeeding can be related to a dichotomous view of women. Negative attitudes toward public breastfeeding might stem from the difficulty to view breasts, which are considered as sexual, in the maternal context of breastfeeding. We predict that the MWD IAT and the explicit MWD will be correlated with both negative feelings and attitudes towards breastfeeding in public.

q4.value:
Hypothesis1: MWD (3 measures) would be correlated.
Hypothesis 2: MWD measures would predict negative attitudes and feelings towards public breastfeeding (as measured by the three measurements for public breastfeeding). 
Exploratory: It is possible that more subtle measurements of breastfeeding attitudes will be correlated with the MWD IAT (or/and the rating picture task), while the more direct measures (attitudes) will be correlated with the explicit MWD.
Hypothesis 3: Sexual satisfaction would mediate the relationship between MWD (tested in 3 different models, one for each variables) and relationship satisfaction.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
